title: They got it right the first time
content: OK this review is more an essay about what Raiders is NOT, rather than a review of what it is.It is NOT "Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark". That was a clumsy attempt to force this movie into the later series' branding structure - something invented decades after Raiders was created. It is and always will be "Raiders of the Lost Ark". Thankfully the tinkering has been limited to the title, and the film itself avoided the kind of disastrous meddling that Lucas inflicted on the original Star Wars trilogy.Raiders is not the sequels. Those are smudged by the fingerprints of studio execs and money counters. But Raiders feels like a passion project by two baby boomer film buffs with little interference (or interest) from a studio. And like an independent film, Raiders was not a huge hit initially in theaters, much to Paramount's dismay. But after the film found larger success with home viewing, naturally Paramount's corporate owners saw the opportunity to profit from sequels that could draw in the widest audience possible. For studio execs, that meant making subsequent entries "kid friendly" or, in reality, a dulling down of Indiana Jones.Raiders is not a "kids' movie". Lucas and Spielberg created Raiders as a love letter to the cinematic tough guy antiheroes that adults would remember. But the two couldn't help but be influenced by the gritty realism movement in 1970s cinema. Indy is tough and stoic, rough around the edges, but capable of making mistakes and getting hurt. He's charming and also a jerk. When in real danger, he shoots to kill. To their credit, Lucas and Spielberg didn't under estimate the intelligence or resilience of the audience, including kids.Raiders is not just an action movie. Unlike in countless movies that it inspired, the characters and story come first. In the 21st century, action or adventure movies are built around spectacle. Audiences experience movies as an assault on the senses. The level of spectacle and eye candy in Raiders feels refreshing, even quaint.Raiders is not magic. Indy's world is heightened and stylized, certainly. A supernatural presence appears for a reason and within the logical boundaries established in this world. When its purpose is fulfilled, the other-worldly tone retreats conclusively. Elements of the beyond are not pushed to the point of complete absurdity or insult the intelligence of the audience.Great flick. Ten out of ten stars.

title: The spirit of adventure pervades this film from start to finish.
content: The spirit of adventure pervades this film from start to finish. Historically, adventure is almost always intertwined with travel as well as exploration. Therefore, Mr. Jones is an archaeologist. And in order to immediately dot the "i", it should be noted that the "Hunters" are very far from the reliability. Archaeologists will surely notice many simulated nuances when events take place in ancient buildings, and historians will definitely see objects in the frame that did not actually exist in 1936. But this is a movie about adventure, not historical events.In my opinion, to some extent, this film can literally be called the perfect adventure film. It has all the necessary components: a fascinating story, a bewitching atmosphere, a disturbing horror-mystery with fantasy elements, romance, action and a perfect ending in which the good win and the evil brutally get what they deserve. Therefore, who has not seen, do not waste time and enjoy watching.

title: Good entertainment
content: If you don't nitpick too much, there's lots to like about this rollicking tale of the WWII era quest by an American archaeologist cum adventurer, Indiana Jones, to find a biblical treasure, the Ark of the Covenant, before the Nazis do. It's meant to be cartoonish in style, so just drink in the beautiful settings (Tunisia, Egypt, Nepal, South America), the excellent John Williams score, and the script and direction that, at times, can be witty and inventive. Harrison Ford was born to play the role of Indiana Jones, and he's actually intelligent - well done for casting him ahead of some dumb hunk who would not have been so believable as a brainy archaeologist. Ford is excellent at playing the guy who can get himself out of any hairy situation, although most of the time, e.g. in the Amazon rainforest, it's just not believable that he would not be slaughtered immediately by that indigenous army who know that forest back to front. In addition, the indigenous men are improbably inaccurate archers in running after Ford. Karen Allen, as Ford's old girlfriend Marion, is one of the best things about the movie. The producers are ground-breaking, or maybe it's the first time since those feisty heroines of the 1940s, in depicting a lead woman as clothed, intelligent, physically strong and actually saving Indiana many times. She's fantastic. The scene of her out-drinking a local woman in Nepal is priceless. She deserved her own movie. The bad guys are the most cliched characters in this movie. They may as well have a sign on their head - "I'm evil." But as I said, it's meant to be a rollicking adventure, and not a serious drama that you'd criticise too heavily as not being realistic.

title: A Fun Rousing Adventure Imprinted on Pop Culture
content: Watched Indiana Jones And The Raiders Of The Lost Ark The Cast Was Stellar With Mark Harrison Ford(Blade Runner) as Indiana Jones, Karen Allen(National Lampoons Animal House) as Marion Ravenwood, Denholm Elliot(Alfie) as Dr.Marcus Brody, John Rhys-Davies(The Nativity) as Sallah, Roshan Alfred Molina as Satipo, Ronald Lacey(Gawain And The Green Knight) as Major Arnold Toht And Paul Freemen(The Dogs Of War) as Rene Belloq.The Film was the great debut of Indiana Jones also it was a great introduction to Indy also he is an adventurer he doesn't seek riches just the pursuit of the knowledge he sought the Ark to help fund his academics also it was a fu rousing adventure film I still like The Crusade Better this is 2nd Best.Fantastic Cinematography By Douglas Slocombe(Never Say Never Again) , Amazing Writing By Lawrence Kasdan(The Empire Strikes Back) , Steven Spielberg(Jaws), and Amazing Score from John Williams(Star Wars) A Fun Rousing Adventure Imprinted on Pop Culture 8/10

title: Prime Adventure Even If It Goes A Bit Far
content: The main intent of Raiders of the Lost Ark is to be a fun adventurous ride and you have to give it that. The film kicks of the action right from the beginning and goes from one to another over the course of the film slowing down only for a moment and keeping exposition to a minimum. However, while the film keeps it all under two hours it does feel a bit much. From the number of set-piece to the size of each. Each one builds from one thing to the next getting more extravagant as it continues into a bit of mumbo-jumbo. This was the start of extensive and wild action scenes in both Spielberg's career and all of cinema. While the movie is undoubtedly a classic, its influence (which is on almost every action movie made after it) has been more negative. Raiders of the Lost Ark tried to make movies funner but it also made them dumber.Pretty much all the other characters in it are cartoonish but Harrison Ford is, of course, great as the movies biggest appeal: Indiana Jones.

title: Such an amazing adventure movie...
content: Being a kid back in the day when the 1981 movie "Raiders of the Lost Ark" was originally released and growing up watching the Indiana Jones movies, I have to say that this movie from director Steven Spielberg is a classic. It is a movie that has as much appeal today as it did back when it was just released.The storyline in "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is one that embodies adventure and a hero character that you just can't help but like, admire and want to be. Such is the phenomena that is Indiana Jones, a true pop culture phenomena in every aspect. And that is what makes these movies so very enjoyable. Writers Lawrence Kasdan, George Lucas and Philip Kaufman put together a script and storyline that not only is amazingly entertaining and enjoyable, but also highly memorable. It is an adventure with a wide appeal to every age group and member in the audience, both young and old alike.The acting in "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is good, and they definitely had a great cast ensemble for the movie. Of course Harrison Ford has managed to become an epitome of Indiana Jones and no one can fill the shoes that he has left for this character and the franchise. Harrison Ford simply is Indiana Jones. But also with the likes of Karen Allen, Paul Freeman, John Rhys-Davies, Ronald Lacey, Denholm Elliott, Alfred Molina and Wolf Kahler on the cast list, then you are in very capable hands throughout the course of the 115 minutes that the movie runs for."Raiders of the Lost Ark" has a great character gallery, with very memorable characters, both good and evil. And that is a great testimony to the writing skills of Lawrence Kasdan, George Lucas and Philip Kaufman.There is a good amount of action and thrills throughout the course of the 115 minute that "Raiders of the Lost Ark" runs for, and the audience is taken along on a rather enjoyable and entertaining thrill ride with director Steven Spielberg at the helm.Visually then the effects in "Raiders of the Lost Ark" are good. Sure, some of them do come off as a bit antequated when you watch the movie today, but generally it has withstood the passing of time quite admirably.If you enjoy adeventure movies, and not already familiar with "Raiders of the Lost Ark", then it is definitely a movie you have to track down and watch.My rating of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" lands on a ten out of ten stars.

title: Revolutionary matinee homage
content: (I will note that I have rated this trilogy as a whole - this movie is rather a 9, though a 10 would perhaps be fair)Raiders of the Lost Ark, Steven Spielberg's iconic adventure that harkens back to the classic matinees and adventures and one of the few films in the genre nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars.It is of course entirely deserving of all the praise it has gotten - like his starring role in the Star Wars trilogy before it, Harrison Fors gives the performance of a life time and the overall tone is somewhat reminiscent of Star Wars. It's just lighthearted and fun, good vs. Evil and a colourful cast of memorable characters.The cinematography, cutting and editing is incredible, and it showcases some iconic and incredible action set pieces.Overall, an incredible and fun adventure that goes without saying, is definitely recommended!

title: An old school classic....
content: I decided during the winter break to look at a few old school movies that were widely praised by its audience and so one of them was Indiana Jones.This movie really had everything from a bit of romance to great comedy. During its time this film was like no other; Unique, different, and action packed. And a lot of the movies today that I have watched and which I really liked have similar aspects and qualities to that have Indiana Jones.Overall a enjoyable movie even with it's somewhat lacking effects, it had a great cast and will be memorable from audiences from all ages young and old. It's a must watch if you prefer classics over modern movies. Rewatchable: Unlikely...

title: Haters of the Lost Ark
content: I guess you can say I am a hater of this movie, even though I don't think it's that bad. It's just not that good either. Don't get me wrong, the music and Indiana character are both iconic. Everyone knows the theme and recognizes the hero with the hat and whip. I think that's why this movie gets so much hype. It's so iconic and nostalgic that people overlook everything else.The story is pretty mindless. It's a race to see who can find the ark first. Indy always gets outsmarted by the other guys but manages to escape again and again. There's no real dialog that has any depth to it and as great as the soundtrack is, it is also distracting. The ending is kind of lackluster. I mean, the face melting is cool, but afterwards it just ends with no real resolution.In my opinion, it's just an ok action/adventure movie that happens to have a really charismatic and iconic hero. I'm not even a fan and I was Indiana Jones for Halloween one year. But if you want a great adventure movie, there are others that beat this by a mile. In my opinion, the Goonies is a 10x better adventure movie. The characters have emotions and a reason to fight, the bad guys are funny but not in a cheesy way, the soundtrack is incredible but not intruding, and the ending has a true resolution that leaves you smiling. To me, that's a 10/10, which is why this is a 6/10.

title: Action, action and more action.
content: A film that gave us a story packed full of action, amazing stunt work, a really imaginative production design, a fantastic score and lastly one of the greatest heroes in cinema, Indiana Jones, an archaeologist/adventurer. The film released in 1981 took inspiration from the swashbuckling 1940s/1950s era of Hollywood, in that respect the premise is simple, our hero must find the treasure, rescue the girl and save the world. The film was largely shot on location in North Africa and this adds a touch of grit and realism which really benefits the film, you see the little flies landing on the actors faces during a few close ups and see the sweat rolling off their brows. The film largely takes place in one location Egypt, with the very early part set in South and North America.The Blu Ray transfer looks really great, with lots of rich earthy colours, reds, browns, sandy yellows, greys & dark leathery brown, these tend to make up most of the costume design. The supporting cast are also very well written and good fun too, from the heroes to the villains. The tone of the film is adventurous and the pacing certainly gives the whole thing a massive injection of energy. There's a slight theme of magic v rationality, as the initially skeptical Indiana Jones is confronted with the dangerous reality of the power held within the lost ark he is seeking.There is not much in the way of character development, though the relationship between Dr Jones and the feisty and rather attractive Marion Ravenwood changes over the course of the film. The movies hail from the decade that was the 1980s and so we're given a slightly stronger female love interest than audiences were used to in the 1960s and 1970s, Marion's character shares similarities with Princess Leia in the Empire Strikes Back or Charlie Blackwood in Topgun, beautiful and alluring but also a tough-minded woman who takes no nonsense and will stand up for herself. You could certainly get away with more too in the 1980s cinema than you can today, the film features quite a lot of violence, blood and swearing for something that children were allowed to watch, I doubt a PG film today could get away with anything like this.The film's logic is not intended to be taken as 100% realistic, a main character in a realistic action film would probably die after the first 10 minutes. For this reason it's possible to overlook the numerous injuries Jones picks up which would put most people into hospital. The fact the German's had no presence in Egypt is also something you have to overlook in the film, the British in fact were in control of Egypt in 1936, it would have made more sense if the Fascists were working from Libya, but then Libya doesn't feel as Biblical as Egypt does, so I suppose the location was switched. You'd have to be pretty picky though to let things like this stop you from enjoying the film, the whole thing is about a search for a magic chest.

title: yes, movies can be better than this
content: A brave American archaeologist defies, almost singlehandedly, Nazis, Arabs and a sleazy Canadian in an ongoing pursuit filled with gunshots, explosions and fist fighting in order to bring to the safe hands of the US academia a significant relic of the Hebrews. Apart from the political undertones, there are way too many predictable things happening in this movie as the 'good' guys win over the 'bad'. Seeing this movie at the age of 7 must be exhilarating. Seeing it at the age of 14 must be quite fun. But if you are any older than that, most scenes will seem redundant. I believe that most viewers' ecstasy with this movie stems from their nostalgia to when they first saw it and that's legitimate.

title: Second-rate comedy
content: I've been avoiding Indiana Jones like the plague until tonight when I decided to see what it's all about. And boy was I in for a treat! I was laughing so hard at every action scene! The music was so laughable, Harrison Ford played worse than Paris Hilton sings and every cliché imaginable was there.The plot is virtually non-existent during the first half of the movie and when the real action finally kicks in, you see Dr. Jones escaping from difficult situations with unbelievable ease, the ridiculous music score serving as another way of applauding his actions. Those were the best bits. Because then you have the totally random ending that turns your laughter into a WTF expression.The characters are paper-thin - not to mention Spielberg's obsession with the Germans (or anyone non-American or non-Jewish) who have to be depicted as either superevil or superstupid.Unintentionally funny, totally predictable and a waste of money and film. How anyone with an average IQ can enjoy this is beyond me.

title: Aged very well, still good.
content: After 42 years there is a new Indiana Jones and that was for me a good excuse to rewatch all the others. So I started with Raiders Of The Lost Ark, a movie that has a special meaning for me as it was the first movie I ever watched at the cinema, when it was still something special to watch a movie on a big screen. My godfather took me to the cinema and as a young kid I was incredibly wowed by this movie from Steven Spielberg. I still consider it as the perfect example for how a movie should be in the Adventure genre. It aged very well, I still enjoyed it like the first time. Harrison Ford is perfect in the role of Indie, makes me curious to see how he does in the latest one, as I can't see him jumping and running around anymore like he used to do. Karen Allen is eye candy. She has that innocent sexy look and is a pleasure to watch. Raiders Of The Lost Ark is already so old but still one of the better ones from the Indiana Jones franchise, and a reference for the adventurous movies.

title: Absolute GOLD
content: Holy friggin' toss buckets, I haven't seen this since I was...12 maybe, and yet it's still every bit as good as I remember. Like, I was starting to wonder if maybe I was wrong when I said that Spielberg does in fact, deserve his status as one of the greats after I only thought that Jaws was good and not great, but oh my god yes, yes, yes he does.I think this might actually be one of those rare flawless films, and you know I don't say that lightly if you've read my reviews for my 10/10 films, so let me lay it all out...Harrison Ford certainly does not have many roles that many people would claim are better, or even equal to, Han Solo, but goddamn I think Indy might just be better. And he's so funny, so likable, so badass, yet feels so...human. He never feels indestructible, or like he doesn't ever cock up, and more action films need to bloody remember that. And holy god does 1981 Harrison Ford have this bisexual positively reeling...no I refuse to not mention that.Karen Allen as well...why the hell does she not have more of a career? Why is she hardly in anything else that anyone would know her from? She's feisty, she takes no crud from anyone, and yes, maybe she also has me reeling. Leave me alone.Paul Freeman played one of the best and most sickeningly charming villains of all time in Belloq, and even having just rewatched Lord Of The Rings recently, yes, Sallah is a better role from John Rhys-Davies than Gimli. Basically what I'm saying is that every single one of the characters is perfect, their dialogue is perfect, and every single one of the actors playing them is perfect also.The story is kind of simple, yes, but does it need to do anything more than what it does? Hell no, this might be one of the best scripts ever written for how much it is consistently squeezing every last drop of adventure, tension, and excitement out of the narrative, and this is Spielberg at the absolute top of his game. It might well have one of the best scripts ever written, but if Spielberg wasn't in the director's chair on this (or if Douglas Slocombe wasn't DP), then it might not even be remembered nowadays.And while it is a tight, tight, TIGHT competition for the crown, this might just have John Williams' best work in it too. The score is breathtaking, and really, just the sound in general of this film is amazing. No film has ever had a gunshot or punching sound effect quite like this one.And really, if I'm even taking time to praise the gunshot and punching sound effects, that should just tell you everything you need to know about how perfect I consider this film to be.Why the hell haven't I watched this since my early teens, I'm a damn idiot.

title: An Unmatchable Adventure Classic
content: Staring Harrison Ford, directed by Steven Spielberg, and produced by George Lucas, "Raiders Of The Lost Ark" brought together three legends of 1980s Hollywood for a truly magical piece of cinema. An adventure film in the purest form, "Raiders Of The Lost Ark" is like "Star Wars" in the sense that it took an outmoded, B-movie genre and brought it back with unprecedented scale and dignity.Harrison Ford plays Indiana Jones, an archeologist in 1936 tasked with finding the Ark of the Covenant before the Nazis do. The Ark - a hollowed chest from the Bible, claimed to hold the original Stone Tablets of the Ten Commandments - carries an awesome power that, if fallen into the wrong hands, could be catastrophic.Jones' quest sends him on a worldly journey. The film begins in a Peruvian jungle, then after brief stint in the United States, travels to Nepal, Egypt, and the ocean before climaxing on a small island in the Aegean Sea. Not all scenes were filmed on-location, but the settings are convincing enough. Practical effects and miniatures also make "Raiders Of The Lost Ark" a relic of the 1980s American blockbuster.It is also an accessible film for people of all ages and interests. Not a science fiction or fantasy piece, it does not cater to an esoteric fan base. History buffs will enjoy the film for its archeological themes, but it is not made for academics alone. Regular moviegoers seeking action-packed thrills will find it just as satisfying.Furthermore, the story is smart, but simple enough for kids to enjoy just as much as adults. The good guys and the bad guys are clear, as are the simple messages of justice and heroism. This is thanks to Harrison Ford's spot-on embodiment of Jones, as well as that special Spielberg touch. The director evokes something of a John Ford Western in this movie, but cuts out anything archaic while adding in a dash of James Bond excitement. There are chases and shootouts, along with romance and humor, and an iconic John Williams score to tie it all together. Not a single frame passes as dull.The movie is not just easy to enjoy, but it is hard to imagine anyone not enjoying it. Many movies have tried to capture the spirit of Indiana Jones over the years, but barring the sequels to "Raiders Of The Lost Ark," few have hit the mark. It's sense of adventure feels familiar and easy to emulate, but somehow, it remains one-of-a-kind.

title: "I'm making this up as I go"
content: I believe that there is no need to give a summary of the most legendary adventure film ever made. When you think of Harrison Ford, you think of Indiana Jones. And don't lie you think of "Star Wars". It may be a bigger and more popular franchise, but I bet Indiana is everyone's first association. A charismatic professor of archaeology who swings his whip in remote places of the third world, overcomes all obstacles with ease of a comic-book hero, a charmer who seduces women and audiences and who has marked childhood for many generations. Technically excellent, visually impressive (except for the quite silly special effects towards the end), atmospheric, with perfectly balanced elements of adventure, action, humor, and romance. It may not be a masterpiece of cinematography, but with its spirit and influence on the genre as well as on generations of viewers, it certainly deserves cult status.8/10

title: Perhaps the best of the franchise
content: Possibly the best of the franchise. A perfect pulp adventure movie, with so much energy, charisma and sense of fun. Harrison Ford was born to be Indiana Jones (and Han Solo).

title: The one that started it all
content: Raiders of the Lost Ark stars Harrison Ford and is directed by Steven Spielberg. Raiders of the Lost Ark follows Indiana Jones as he races against the Nazis to obtain the Lost ark of the covenant. Fresh off of completing Star Wars George Lucas and Steven Spielberg came up with this idea as they were on vacation. And instead of forgetting about it the next day or creating a "movie of the week" that nobody would care about, they actually decided to let their imaginations run wild. Now I'm sure that before they created Raiders of the Lost Ark they saw a lot of movies involving treasure hunting and decided to give it a makeover. And from their they decided to turn something that sounds like it came out of a B movie and transformed it into an A++ movie after the project was finished. But Raiders of the Lost Ark is The Godfather of treasure hunting movies and all the treasure hunting movies are good, but they don't have that passion and majestic as Raiders of the Lost Ark offers. I should also add that it's also the inspiration for many movies and video games over the years and has been referenced in many pop cultures. You can not turn on the T.V. And having someone reference Indiana Jones or the scenes that gave birth to countless of directors and writers imitating those scenes. This movie and Star Wars were the first movies to open my eyes to many movies to come. And there are many movies out there that brilliantly fantastic, but Raiders of the Lost Ark and Star Wars were the first to do that. Besides Steven Spielberg, George Lucas, and John Williams, I don't know if the other crew who were in Star Wars also were involved in making this. I would like to think so as they borrow elements from Star Wars such as music, special effects, costumes, to just about anything you can think of and then it into something simple and easy without anything being over dramatic. I also applaud Steven Spielberg and George Lucas for having the ability to create one movie that blew people's minds and creating another movie with an iconic character for many years that people wish they could be. Because in the end who doesn't want to be Indiana Jones? So in the end every thing about this move is pure cinematic perfection that is worth exploring again and again.

title: Hasn't aged well
content: I have always loved this movie but haven't watched it for maybe 7 or 8 years and so I sat down to watch it with my wife who had never seen it. I was excited to see her reaction but it was mine that was the problem - it just looked cheesy, out of date, sexist and generally pants and I wondered what I ever saw in it. Shame

title: Overrated
content: Raiders Of The Lost Ark is widely regarded as the quintessence of the adventure-action movie. However, there is so much to say about it is hard to understand how it can be such highly considered.Everything isn't bad. There are, in particular, very good actions scenes such as the opening scene or the one in the temple with the snakes, and some well thought-out touches of humour. But we are under the impression that the plot is secondary, in fact you forget about it after some time, and that it is just a pretext for blowing us away with those action scenes, like blockbusters do nowadays.The flaws are obvious, from the shallow characters to the choppy rhythm or the mediocre editing with a lot of jump cuts or continuity errors. A few extremely far-fetched scenes also discredit the movie.Raiders Of The Lost Ark is therefore far from perfect and certainly cannot pretend to the rank of masterpiece some give it.

title: A classic for all time
content:
What can I possibly add to what has already been written? This film is a "masterpiece". It's placed in quotations because that word is bandied about on here for films that aren't fit to lace this movies' boots. This movie should be preserved for all eternity as a template on how to make an incredibly entertaining and wonderful film, and as I said earlier, there isn't much I can add to what has already been said about Raiders. Let's just say that there are only so many films I plan on introducing to my children when they get old enough and this film is amongst that list.
Harrison Ford was amazing in the titular role, and the supporting cast added immense scale and brevity to the work HF was doing as Indy.
Spielberg and Lucas created a character and movie for the ages.Keep an eye out for one of the most iconic film sequences of all time as well!Make sure that you give this film the rating and love it deserves. Thank you for reading!

title: First and still the best (spoilers)
content: Raiders of the Lost Ark is an action masterpiece. There's not one bit of fat on its bones. There's not one wasted moment. It flows exactly like an adventure movie should  it continually moves forward, breathlessly driving you towards the conclusion; it's incredible fun.The reason why the film works so well is because the script is so tight. The exposition is clear and well delivered, meaning that you know precisely what's at stake, small character details are set up early on and paid off later and the dialogue is incredibly pithy. It's a masterclass in film writing.However, this would mean nothing if all the other elements didn't come together. Thankfully they do. Spielberg's direction is superb, Harrison Ford is perfect as the hero, Karen Allen is wonderful as the heroine and the music is out of this world. Plus the action is kick ass.My favourite action scene is the fight with Pat Roach by the plane. Quite unusually for a film hero, Indy doesn't mind fighting dirty. He kicks Roach in the balls, he throws sand in his face and he even bites him. Indy doesn't have to win a fight fairly. And it's also unusual for a film hero to be so vulnerable. We rarely see anyone get a scratch or put in any real jeopardy. But here Indy gets his arse handed to him. The only reason he survives is because he's so wily  after getting beaten and bruised for a while he leads Roach into getting chopped up by the plane's rotor blades.My second favourite action sequence is when Indy chases after the Ark and recovers it by hijacking a Nazi truck. After the CGI mess of Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, it's great to see old-fashioned stunts. It's a much better way of letting you get absorbed by the action  even though you know it's a film, you know someone actually had to do this, making everything much more impressive to watch. The best stunt is when Indy is thrown through the front window and has to pull himself along the bottom of the truck. He manages to do this and then hooks his whip under the bottom so that he's dragged along the ground. He then manages to get back on the truck and back in the cabin. It's a joy to behold and allows you to immerse yourself in the action.Another great thing about the sequence is that once again we're shown Indy's vulnerability. As he's driving he gets shot in the arm. And then later a guy punches him in his injured arm and throws him out of the truck. Therefore when Indy comes back and beats the crap out of this guy, it's doubly satisfying, because not only is the guy a damn Nazi, but he also had the audacity to try and injure our hero. And the blood and guts reminds me of how gritty the film is. Not only do we have Indy getting shot in the arm and then having the wound beaten, but earlier on a guy gets shot in the face  lots of blood pours down from the hole in his skull. Oh, and he's also on fire. Excellent.But as well as this there's also stuff that is just plain over the top. The melting faces for instance and Belloq's head exploding. This scared the hell out of me as a kid and I'm still amazed that stuff like this was included in a 'kids' film.However, the scene that terrified me the most as a kid was the scene where Marion gets mugged by skeletons and we then see a large snake oozing from a skull's mouth. I was so traumatised I refused to watch the film for years. But now the vague horror element is another reason I adore the movie. It sets it apart from almost every action/adventure film that came before it and nothing else has managed to better it, even subsequent Indiana Jones films.But watching the film now it's quite unusual to note that Indy doesn't kill any of the three main villains. They're all killed by the Ark. Indy instead just closes his eyes and lets 'god' do the rest. It's a strange ending but one that works perfectly. Indy isn't a killing machine. He's someone trying to do the right thing. And at the end he's rewarded by, well, not having his face melted off.Another reason why Raiders stands out is because of its heroine. She's one of the best in modern cinema  a tough woman who constantly shows her toughness without having to resort to ridiculous feats of physicality. We don't see her pummel men who are twice her size, but we do see her out smart them and drink them under the table. As well as this she has great chemistry with Indy. For instance, there's the marvellous scene where she tries to look after our injured hero and he cries like a girl every time she touches him. He then points out a few places where it doesn't hurt, which she kisses. It's a lovely scene. And I also like the bit of slapstick humour earlier where Indy gets a mirror smashed in his face when Marion turns it over.This leads me to another reason why Raiders is brilliant. It's very funny. You have a monkey giving a Nazi salute, Indy nonchalantly shooting a swordsman, Sallah's cowardly reactions at the Well of Souls and the Gestapo man plunging his hand in the snow after he gets it burnt while trying to grab an extremely hot bronze medallion. The humour is great.And on top of all of this cinematic goodness  the humour, the action, the adventure  you have one of the best opening sequences in film. It's a bravura piece of film-making  everything clicks perfectly.

title: Still good!
content: The Convenant opened - that will be Hollywood classics for years. In fact, to sum it all up: hundreds of years from now, I wouldn't be surprised if this is still considered one of the great adventure films of all time.The action scenes are varied, which means a lot. You don't get the same kind of jolt of adventure. You get fist fights, battles with snakes, with airplane propellers, guns, knives, poison dates, fires, supernatural plague-type winds, chases through city streets, caves, mountains....you name it, it's all in here.This movie can wear you out, which is almost a negative. The music can get too loud, the action too much, Karen Allen's mouth too profane; the credibility too much to believe, the theology too weird, etc, but no one can deny this is a fun ride all the way through. You take none of it seriously and just enjoy the adventure.Coming on the heels of Star Wars, this really made Harrison Ford a mega-star. It didn't do much for the rest of the cast but it sure boosted Ford's stock.

title: Timeless adventure classic
content: There are no set qualities for a great film. Some movies like Citizen Kane are towering Cathedrals, crowned with outstanding lead performances, their every shot awash with gravitas and innovation, two hour pieces of high art with relatively simple stories. Other films are great stories, superbly told, like The Shawshank Redemption, Braveheart and Slumdog Milllionaire. And then there are films like this one which are a joyous, fun celebration of all the things we love about movies and film making.Every scene of this is fun and enjoyable. A rollicking chase between two rival archaeologists as they travel all over the world (the film using world maps so we can keep track of the action) in search of the mystical "ark of the covenant." Throw in some Nazis, snake phobia, cutting edge (for the time) special effects, a damsel in distress and the Saturday matinée feel and you have an adventure film like no other to that point in time.For star Harrison Ford, this film, on the back of his turn as Han Solo in an expanded role in 1980's The Empire Strikes Back confirmed his status as the pre eminent leading man of his time, and from the start, this is his movie. We follow his adventures for an inordinate number of minutes before the director shows us his face, we see him fearlessly tackle big hairy spiders, leaps of doom, deadly arrows and rolling stone balls before the film is 15 minutes old. We also see him lose his first big battle on screen with his rival Belloq. And in those first 15 minutes we learn everything we need to about his character and the film. Indy is fearless, principled, a bit of a screw up and not a particularly good archaeologist. No wonder he has to work as a teacher to pay the bills. From that point on he becomes all things to all people. The film rarely lets up on the action, with chase after chase, and usually ending in Indy being outwitted by his smarter, better resourced rival.Ford is absolutely superb. While I personally believe that the film still would have been a success had Spielberg's original choice for the role, Tom Selleck, been available, it is now impossible to see anyone else in the role. Spielberg has also surrounded Ford with a great supporting cast including Denholm Elliott, John Rhys Davies, Paul Freeman, Karen Allen and Ronald Lacey, as well as a very young Alfred Molina. Allen in particular is great as the love interest/ damsel in distress.The effects, for the time were breathtaking, bringing the settings alive and nearly making us believe that the Nazis faces are melting at the film's end. Some of the blue screen shots leave a little to be desired, but it was still fairly early in the evolution of that film making technology, and so these are forgivable. The set pieces are expertly realized and the fight scenes well choreographed.In the end Raiders is the finest example of the adventure genre, made the more entertaining for the fact that our protagonist is not a particularly successful adventurer. It has enough silly to be fun, without being stupid and remains, more than 30 years on, as one of the most entertaining films not just of its era, but in all of American cinema.

title: Thrilling adventure
content: This is a classic adventure/action film with an engaging storyline and genuine thrills. It really set the scene for exciting blockbusters with memorable theme tunes. However, I personally didn't find it as engaging as Temple of Doom which I think had scarier villains.

title: Warning: Eye Rolling May Cause Dizziness
content: It starts with a scene that would have us believe that an ancient civilization implemented a high-tech security system to safeguard an idol. Yes, the movie is exciting but the action is so utterly ridiculous that it makes James Bond films and "The Road Runner" cartoons look realistic. While it's understandable that one has to suspend disbelief when watching a film, the level of stupidity suggests that Spielberg has no respect for the viewer's intelligence. Scenes such as Jones's stunt under the moving vehicle and the revelation of the contents of the ark are sure to have any adult viewer rolling his eyes so often that there's danger of collapsing from dizziness.

content: At the time this movie was first released, I saw a lot of movies. I pretty much saw every new release as it came out.So, I went to see Caveman (was I the only one who saw Caveman?) and it was billed with a Sneak Preview. The Sneak Preview was unnamed. This movie has everything. It is a real treat.

title: "Asps. Very dangerous. You go first."
content: FILM: 10/10.Raiders of the Lost Ark is a timeless classic and, without a doubt, my favorite Indiana Jones movie. From start to finish, it is a flawless masterpiece that captivates audiences with its gripping story and impeccable casting.This film is the perfect blend of action, adventure, history, and the supernatural. George Lucas's story is a true gem, while John Williams' iconic score adds another layer of magic to the entire experience. The film has a heightened afternoon-matinee feel, with its ridiculously over-the-top sound effects that make guns sound like cannons and punches like body slams.Steven Spielberg's direction is masterful, and his control over every aspect of the film is evident. Right from the opening scene, he effortlessly establishes the characters and tone, immediately immersing the viewers in this thrilling world. Harrison Ford shines as the iconic Indiana Jones, and it's his portrayal that truly makes the film work. Indy is a complex character who exhibits courage, fear, toughness, tenderness, brutality, and humor, all of which Ford captures flawlessly.The fight and action scenes in Raiders of the Lost Ark are nothing short of spectacular. Each one is smartly staged and offers something different, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. It's hard not to get caught up in the excitement and adventure as Indy races against time to uncover the mysteries and protect ancient artifacts.The chemistry between Harrison Ford and Karen Allen is palpable, with Allen serving as the perfect foil for Ford's Indy. Additionally, John Rhys-Davies delivers an immensely enjoyable performance that adds depth and humor to the film.Raiders of the Lost Ark is a true classic in every sense of the word. It has stood the test of time and continues to enchant audiences with its thrilling storyline, well-crafted characters, and unforgettable moments. If you're looking for a film that will transport you to a world of adventure and leave you with a sense of wonder, look no further than Raiders of the Lost Ark.FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-rayVIDEO: 9.5/10.Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: ExcellentAUDIO: 8.5/10.Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Good, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: ExcellentMOOFIEMETER: 10/10.

title: Greatest Adventure Film
content:
Raiders of the Lost Ark is one of the greatest adventure films ever. It combines prime entertainment with purposeful substance. Clearly, Indiana Jones is a movie character icon, but the plot is equally significant to the film's success. The search for the Ark has mystery, excitement, romance, action, and thematic weight. Furthermore, Jones evolves from a practical cynic into a believer in powers beyond his understanding. The bittersweet ending underscores this by denying Jones' desires but providing an emotional need instead. Plus, Ford is the perfect embodiment of Jones' larger than life persona. Ford is Indiana Jones, and Jones is Harrison Ford.Meanwhile, Raiders is driven by its filmmaking. The cinematography uses dramatic composition, lighting, and movement to intensify adventure and meaning. The editing is energetic during action and efficient during exposition. The exaggerated sound heightens combat and supernatural elements. The legendary music and production design are critical to Indiana's iconic pop culture status. Also, the effects are complex and tangible, making the film a genuine thrill ride. Lastly, the direction unites these ingredients into an irresistible journey that's truly lightning in a bottle. Ultimately, the universal love for Raiders of the Lost Ark is undeniably justified.Writing: 9/10

Acting: 8/10

Sound: 10/10

title: Indiana Jones Versus A Bunch Of Nazis
content: Spielberg pays tribute to the golden age of serials. Harrison Ford and Karen Allen are perfectly cast as is the creepy Nazi artifact hunter Major Toht played with much gusto by the late Ronald William Lacey. Thrills and spills for the whole family.

title: indiana jones and Raiders of the Lost Ark
content: Great movie with great characters, Harrison Ford's acting was so amazing that I can't imagine anyone else playing a role, I loved Salah's character, he was a great character, the girl's character in the movie was annoying often and I hated her. She but sometimes she was an excellent character, the story of the movie was good and the ending was shocking, the action scenes in the movie were excellent, the soundtrack in the movie was amazing, I recommend watching it.

title: ( American B +Movie ) My Ratings 8/10
content: Everyone has that movie that traumatized them as a child but didn't really affect anyone else. For me, that was Raiders of the Lost Ark (and Who Framed Roger Rabbit, but that's another story). It's the snakes really that did it, and godamn that snake scene near the end is still difficult for me to watch. Beyond that though, it's a shame it took me so long to give this film another look, because it's really a perfect adventure film. Not an action film (though there is action in it) but an adventure film. That's a genre we don't really see a lot anymore, and it's a real shame. There is such a spirit of fun and adventure to this whole movie that, besides the snakes, it's a real joy to watch

title: A timeless adventure, early Spielberg, set in 1936.
content: Although my review is dated June 2000, when I originally posted my comments, what I am writing now (January 2023) are entirely new comments, having just watched this movie for the 438th time. Well, I exaggerate a bit!Now I like to look at the movie two ways. First, the core story. We have a mild-mannered 30-something Dr. Jones, professor of Archaeology who as a side job searches for Antiquities. His arch-rival Belloq yet again steals a valuable item that Jones has just discovered, but back home is approached about a new challenge, The Ark of the Covenant which they believe Hitler's men are on the verge of discovering.So the core story is an American "good vs evil", of getting the best of the Nazis and preserving a valuable artifact for the civilized world. The mild-mannered professor springs into action and shows he cannot be defeated, whether by fist or by use of his trusty bullwhip.The second way is the style of the movie. Although Spielberg was already in his mid-30s he had only a few years earlier directed "Jaws" and "Close Encounters." We didn't have the internet back in 1981, we generally knew very little about actors and directors. Now that we do, and understand how Spielberg started of as a youngster making movies at home, his style in "Raiders" now makes more sense.While the subject is serious the movie is shot in a grand Saturday matinee adventure style. Lots of action, lots of humor, and playing fast and loose with customs and morals. When you re-watch it a lot certain things are very obvious, like the remotely activated pole that causes the truck to turn over, or the trench under the low-speed truck when Jones is working his way to the rear. And a few other things.Frankly, re-watching in now (2023) the movie doesn't have the luster that I remember when I saw it in the theater 40 years ago. My memory of "Raiders" is better than the movie really is. But I still consider it to be one of the best adventure movies of all time. Harrison Ford has been just perfect as Indiana Jones and I will continue to watch it every 2 or 3 years.I've seen it so many times now I find myself saying certain lines with them, "They're digging in the wrong place!" Many reviews focus on how unrealistic some elements are, but that is part of the fantasy, a professor by day fighting off innumerable Nazis. This is more an escape movie than anything else, just a fantasy to watch and enjoy.

title: Tries too hard to become too many things
content: Most people giving this movie 9s and 10s are simply nostalgic because they saw the movie as a kid, fell in love with it many years ago and they remember it very fondly and giving it super generous (but unrealistic) ratings. I too watched this as a kid and loved it back then but after watching this as an adult, I am not impressed anymore.The movie tries to become too many things at once. It tries to become an action movie, horror movie, comedy movie, mystery movie, historical movie, war movie, love movie and superhero movie, spy movie all at once and has no direction. Its storytelling is too clumsy and jumps from place to place without proper transition and it's tiring to even try to follow the story let alone enjoying it. The movie tries to become too many things at once and doesn't become anything in the end.Also Indiana Jones literally beats up the entire German army with his bare fists. Yep, he beats up every German soldier one by one without even using any weapons. I guess the entire WW2 was just a fist fight between two armies and no guns were involved at all. Maybe guns weren't even invited back then.Also how is it that Dr. Jones gets captured like 10 times and his enemies let him go every time? What kind of bad guys are these?This is an ok movie to pass the time but NO WAY it's a 8.4 movie. The movie's rating is inflated by at last 2.5 points by nostalgic folks who remember it as a great movie when they first saw it 25-30 years ago when they were kids.

title: Raiders Has Lots Going For It
content: When I first saw Raiders of the Lost Ark back in 1981 I was quite taken by it. I reveled in the excitement of the adventure it took me on. Having seen it again recently was a slightly different experience. In part because I've grown and changed, and perhaps also because I've since seen so many other films copy elements of this film that it didn't possess that same sense of originality of adventure. Harrison Ford and solid and likeable here. Raiders of the Lost Ark is still fun and still provides a sense of adventure. I also think it is the best of the series as well and worth checking out, in particular on the big screen if possible.

title: An Interesting Ride But Ultimately Falls Short
content: One of the strong points of this film is the detail in the settings and the nature of adventure. However the film falls short in execution.The film opens brilliantly in an enclosed jungle setting and is highly immersive and then paints a picture of Indy's background. Then we move to the colourful Nepal setting and lastly the Egypt setting. At this point of the film I thought it would become an epic picture. However I was quite wrong.The major fallacies of the film are the religious overtones that are ever-present in the film. It becomes suffocating. I know that Hitler actually did send expeditions during the war to uncover certain places/artifacts that would increase the power of the Nazi regime. What doesn't make sense is why Hitler would search for the Ark of the Covenant which is solely Jewish and Hitler despising Jews. It seemed quite illogical.Secondly the score is over the top and actually draws you away from the film. Constantly you will hear the Indiana Jones theme song being pulsated into your ear. It comes to a point where it is incredibly overbearing.Thirdly the action scenes are dull and prolonged. To put it simply the actions scenes are like watching two snails brawling. Being an adventure film of epic proportions this film should have had interesting action scenes however yet again it falls short.The immersion that was seen in the beginning of the film with Indiana searching for the golden artifact completely disappears in the later sections of the film. When Indiana is searching for the Ark the same level of detail and immersion is completely missing and ruins the scene.Overall the movie is enjoyable but the fallacies ultimately cheapen the viewer's experience.

title: No brains
content: It's good to know I'm not the only person in America who thinks "The Raiders of the Lost Ark" is stupid and offensive.  With its villains designed only as punching bags (they are human, none the less...), its heroine intended to be ogled and scream at the right moments, and its pseudo-religious claptrap, all the praise it's gotten says something very disturbing about large numbers of people.

title: A Link to the Past, a Revival of Style
content: There are so many ways in which this film is perfect, most notably is the brilliant re-packaging of old-school action and war films; away from the James-Bond style of the late 60s; away from the Cold-War suspense and intrigue. One of the most endearing features of the picture is that the movie opens with the main character,Indiana Jones' at the close of his current adventure. The technique generates an immediate sense of personal history and intimacy with the main character, and in effect, serves the audience dessert twice.The atmosphere of equal parts impending danger and chronic screw ups is set right from the start, with a lit-fuse pace throughout the movie. Every scene is tight. The sound, the lighting, the dialog,the music, the performances. Every character actor is well-chosen. So many ingredients to enjoy: adventure, humor, mysterious locations, romance, explosions. Only a Nazi could not enjoy this film!

title: Will Rank Among The All-Time Adventure Stories
content: All three Indiana Jones stories were entertaining but this first one was still the best. I would think most people would agree with me on that. They would also agree this film has some very memorable scenes, famous scenes - like the opening one with the gigantic boulder chasing Harrison Ford - to the ending scene with the Ark of the Convenant opened - that will be Hollywood classics for years. In fact, to sum it all up: hundreds of years from now, I wouldn't be surprised if this is still considered one of the great adventure films of all time.The action scenes are varied, which means a lot. You don't get the same kind of jolt of adventure. You get fist fights, battles with snakes, with airplane propellers, guns, knives, poison dates, fires, supernatural plague-type winds, chases through city streets, caves, mountains....you name it, it's all in here.This movie can wear you out, which is almost a negative. The music can get too loud, the action too much, Karen Allen's mouth too profane; the credibility too much to believe, the theology too weird, etc, but no one can deny this is a fun ride all the way through. You take none of it seriously and just enjoy the adventure.Coming on the heels of Star Wars, this really made Harrison Ford a mega-star. It didn't do much for the rest of the cast but it sure boosted Ford's stock.After a long wait, this finally came out on DVD in October of 2003 and it looks great!

title: Even Spielberg doesn't make 'em like this anymore.
content: Inspired by the movies and serials enjoyed by Steven Spielberg and George Lucas in their youth, Raiders Of The Lost Ark is a relentless roller-coaster of a film that sees the bearded movie moguls expertly combining action, romance, horror, adventure, fantasy and comedy; as far as pure entertainment value goes, it doesn't get much better than this.Unlike in their later adventures for Harrison Ford's heroic archaeologist, the pair pitch the level of escapism perfectly, stretching believability to the limits occasionally, but never exceeding them (there's no flying fridges or death defying falls over a cliff in a rubber dinghy in this one). Apart from seriously underestimating the weight of gold (Indy even takes some sand out of the bag he uses to replace a solid gold idol) and expecting the audience to accept that a U-Boat would travel hundreds of miles without submerging, the film is pretty flawless, with classic scene after classic scene brilliantly executed by a Spielberg in his prime.Not yet in his forties, Harrison Ford is still young enough to give the character his all (mind you, being well into his sixties today doesn't seem to have stopped him trying), and he is given able support by a solid cast that includes John Rhys-Davies as brave Egyptian Sallah, Denholm Elliott as fellow history nut Dr. Marcus Brody, Paul Freeman as reprehensible archaeologist Dr. René Belloq, and Karen Allen as Jones's spunky sidekick Marion Ravenwood. As well as terrific performances, the film also boasts superb old-school stunts (ie., pre-CGI), excellent visual effects from Richard Edlund, and even some delightfully gruesome moments that might prove too much for some little ones: a man is impaled on spears, a German soldier is reduced to a red mist by propeller blades, faces are melted, and there is even an exploding head!!! Now that's what I call quality family entertainment!

title: One of my favourite movies!
content:
Frankly one of the best movies ever made! The plot, the excitement, the acting - it's all brilliant! Definitely the best Lucas film ever made, and definitely one of Spielberg's best. It leaves the viewer feeling quite exhilarated and exhausted - in a good way.
Indiana Jones - in his first (chronologically second) movie adventure - must jump into action to save the Ark of the Covenant from being found and taken by the Nazis, who want to use it for world domination.
The film is not historically accurate, but quite fun nonetheless.

title: A classic
content: Fantastic film, from start to finish. The pinnacle of what many have since referred to as the second coming of "the golden age of cinema".Not only does it pace well, and keep you on the edge of your seat, it also plays to a wide audience range. From kids to adults, this film is highly marketable - probably a reason behind its both financial and critical acclaim.Spielberg set out, as I understand, to produce a one-time summer blockbuster, which has turned into one of the most beloved franchises of all time.No doubt the original is the best - although it remains to be seen with the 5th due to come out soon...

title: The Original and the Best
content: Great thrill ride from start to finish with Ford and Allen perfect in the lead roles. Full of ingenious cliffhangers and iconic set piece scenes. One of Spielberg's finest films. Imitated but never bettered.

title: A nice beginning to the hero we love so much
content: Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark is the first of the Indiana Jones franchise that spawn out 3 sequels, a TV series and numerous video games. It is a classic and stood above many in the box office raking in over $380 million dollars. It also won 4 Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects, Best Sound, Best Film Editing and Best Art Direction.The movie pulls surprises after surprises, like what happened when the Ark was opened, that scene alone is not something you will expect as it starts from the time it was opened till when it was shut, you will be stunned.It packages in its 115 minutes run, a bolder chase, arrow flying here and there, submarine, car chase, gun fights, drama, comedy, adventure, Nazis, Gestapo, Arabian men and Spiritual power in high places, all this for your fun and view, in a movie that is shot in numerous locations.There was a scene where Indy is trapped in the well of souls with over 7,000 snakes, now that is a sight you really want to see. The car chase reminded me of the Mad Max movie Road Warrior it was intense, fun and dangerous.The movie plot has our favorite hero, trying to get a solid-gold idol somewhere in the Peruvian jungle in 1936. He gets it then loses the artifact to his rival and the movie antagonist who is French archaeologist named Belloq (Paul Freeman).Indy is recruited by the Army Intelligence to stop the Nazi's who seem to be after the Ark of Covenant so as to gain power to topple the world.So Indy saddles up and goes to Nepal to meet with his Mentor Ravenwood only to discover that he had died, so he is left to ride along Marion (Karen Allen) his daughter to Cairo where they meet Indy's sidekick Sallah (John Rhys-Davies) as they team up to stop the Nazis.The movie is one joy ride from place to place the movie had quite an interesting bunch of characters that will keep you both thrilled and entertained, one character that catches my fancy was the Gestapo. Raiders of the Lost Ark is set to be a sequel to the movie that came after it, as Temple of Doom was set in 1935. The movie has received numerous acclaim ranked 66 in the AFI's top 100 movies 10th Anniversary and also ranked 10th in AFI's top ten thrills.Here is Indiana Jones at the very beginning an intro to the character that we all love and admire, I believe there is no reason why you should not have seen this classic.www.lagsreviews.com

title: I didn't like this film.
content: I'm not going to spend much time on this as I am obviously in a massive minority by not liking it. It's taken me 20 years to finally see this film through to the end.It just bores me completely. It's a part James Bond film, which I've never had any time for. It doesn't seem any better than the 'Mummy' or 'Tomb Raider' type films (ZZZZZZ) where the dialogue is largely incidental & which you can watch with the volume turned down and still follow. They generally concern some pre-historic torch, urn, key, lump of dog turd, that has special powers, that the hero needs to get his hands on & that just doesn't make for an interesting film.I just cannot get into films like this & never have any interests whether they achieve what they're after. In this there were a lot of scenes which seemed to be filling in time. First the Nazi's had the initiative, then Jones, then back to the Nazi's again and this went on & on & on, to the point that it wasn't dis-similar from a Steven Seagal or Van Damme film. Apart from the obvious superior quality of acting in this, the fighting scenes were sometimes laughable.Karen Allen threw in some incredibly wooden acting in her cliched lines she was given. The "I'm your partner" was almost cringe making.There seems an unwritten rule that you are not allowed to comment on Raiders of the Lost Ark without mentioning Star Wars for some reason. So I love Harrison Ford films, I like George Lucas & certainly don't dislike Spielberg. Thus, I have Star Wars as one of only a dozen films in my list at 10/10, it's almost perfect. I myself, wouldn't mention this in the same breath as Star Wars. You immediately feel a part of Star Wars & it's wonderful characters, neither of which apply here.This film has never taken off in England to the extent it has done in the US. I know plenty of adults who've never seen it & many who are not mad over it.But I'll admit I've never found anyone who genuinely dislikes it. Apart from me!3/10

title: Come On...
content: ...It's one of the greatest movies of all time. Humor, heart, story, adventure, action, a director and a star actor at the pinnacle of their game. I have been watching this movie for decades and I'm never not interested in every single second. Such a legendary film.

title: An Iconic Adventure Filled with Thrills and Charm
content: Set in the 1930s, the story follows Indiana Jones, portrayed by Harrison Ford, as he embarks on a perilous quest to find the Ark of the Covenant before the Nazis can seize its power. From the jungles of South America to the deserts of Egypt, the film takes viewers on a thrilling journey filled with treacherous traps, ancient mysteries, and pulse-pounding action sequences.Steven Spielberg's direction is masterful, creating a sense of excitement and wonder throughout the film. The pacing is flawless, with each scene propelling the story forward while keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. From the iconic boulder chase to the intense truck chase, the action sequences are expertly choreographed and executed, showcasing Spielberg's talent for crafting thrilling set-pieces.Harrison Ford's portrayal of Indiana Jones is nothing short of iconic. With his rugged charm, wit, and an undeniable sense of adventure, Ford brings the character to life and solidifies his place in cinematic history. Jones is a charismatic and flawed hero, a mix of intelligence, resourcefulness, and vulnerability, making him relatable and beloved by audiences.The supporting cast is equally impressive. Karen Allen shines as Marion Ravenwood, a spirited and capable love interest for Indiana Jones. Paul Freeman delivers a memorable performance as the cunning and treacherous archaeologist rival, Dr. René Belloq. The chemistry between the characters adds depth and a touch of romance to the film, enhancing the overall experience.John Williams' iconic score is a standout element of the film, capturing the sense of adventure and excitement. The memorable theme music has become synonymous with Indiana Jones and has contributed to the film's lasting impact on popular culture.Thematically, "Raiders of the Lost Ark" explores the enduring appeal of adventure and the thrill of discovery. It pays homage to classic serials and adventure films of the past while infusing them with Spielberg's signature storytelling and visual flair. The film strikes a perfect balance between lighthearted moments and darker, more intense sequences, creating a captivating and entertaining experience for audiences of all ages.In conclusion, "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is an iconic adventure film that continues to captivate audiences with its thrilling action, memorable characters, and sense of charm. Steven Spielberg's direction, Harrison Ford's iconic portrayal of Indiana Jones, and the film's expertly crafted blend of adventure, humor, and excitement make it a true classic. "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is a must-watch for fans of the genre and anyone seeking an unforgettable cinematic adventure.

title: VERY GOOD FILM
content: I see the film as a metaphor for the pursuit of lost or forbidden knowledge and the dangers of uncovering truths that are meant to remain hidden. The Ark of the Covenant represents an ancient power or wisdom that, can have catastrophic consequences. It reflects the tension between sacred knowledge and its misuse by those in positions of power. The Ark of the Covenant represents ancient, suppressed knowledge and technology that possesses immense power and truth about humanity's origins and true history. The Nazis' pursuit of the Ark reflects a broader conspiracy to harness this hidden power for their own nefarious ends. The film suggests that powerful truths about our past are obscured by those in control, and such knowledge, if revealed, could drastically alter our understanding of history and reality.

title: Many amazing nuances and action highlights
content:
(1981) Raiders of the Lost Ark
ACTION ADVENTUREThe first of five Indiana Jones action adventure movies that opens with archeologist, Indy (Harrison Ford) along with some guides attempting to grab a golden artifact while exploring inside of a cave from some South American jungle. And by the time, Indy escapes the cave with the amulet, he is then waiting for him is fellow archaeologist, Belloq (Paul Freeman) waiting outside to take the amulet from him surrounded with natives pointing their arrows at him. And just as they are about to kill him, Indy manages to distract them before he escapes through the jungle onto a floater plane. It appears his fellow peer Belloq is working for the Nazis. Indy is back at the US again instructing his students, and is approached by US agents about instructions involving finding and locating the lost ark before the Nazis do. . The first name Indy is supposed to meet happens to live in Nepal, and by the time he goes their, it turns out he is deceased and that he has a daughter named Marion (Karen Allen) who runs a bar. Coincidentally, it also happens to the time the Nazis show up and try to recover the medallion Indy was looking for. A scuffle happens with the bar burned down to the ground with Indy escaping with Marion with the medallion that is supposed to pin point where the lost ark was buried.Although, entertaining some of the influential scenes also include Indy crawling underneath the truck carrying the ark that stunt is reminiscent to the stunt performed by Yakima Canutt from "Stagecoach"; and the one scene with the guy waving a machete before Indy pulls out his gun was already shown before on a movie called "Seven" released in 1979. Is used for great effect here.

There is no denying that "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is one of the greatest movies in the action/adventure genre. It's one of the most impressive, most memorable, and most dynamically entertaining films I have ever experienced. George Lucas and Lawrence Kasdan delivered lots of unexpected surprises to the whole script, and these surprises just kept on coming. The script is complemented by the slick and elaborate direction by Steven Spielberg. What makes "Raiders of the Lost Ark" stand out in the action/adventure genre, as well as for a winner for fans of this genre, is how smart it is; the film consistently throws in perilous obstacles to keep the film exciting, and we will never know what is coming, and when something happens, it really pays off. Even on repeat viewings, it is still unpredictable and satisfying in every way. Not to mention that the skillful craftsmanship on display will make it an inspiring film for those who want to be a filmmaker for the action/adventure genre.The production design is arresting and tangible, while the sound effects are gripping. From the audacious stunts, to the hard-hitting impact, and to the astonishing effects, The action sequences deliver a lot of sprightly momentum. The unintentionally comedic moments are clever in structure and quite gut-busting in execution, and I laughed at all of these comedic moments. I must add that no animals were hamred in the making of this film, including the snakes. They all spawned a dynamic adventure yarn that is altogether exhilarating, audacious, intelligent, and hilarious. Driven by high energy and melodic emotion, The dramatically invigorating music score by John Williams enhances the film entirely, as it vividly captures every element, and it strongly supports the film's genre and it's theme of heroism.The all of the characters have both brains and brawn that are equally matched. But each of them are distinct in personality. Also, the performances are first-rate indeed, and the interactions between the characters are intriguing and fun to watch. Both the protagonists and the antagonists are archeologists, but different in nationalities; the heroes (the main characters) are Americans, while the villains are Nazis, as they go head to head for the golden ark of god that invokes religious spirits, and the Nazis thought that the spirits will make the army invincible. Harrison Ford plays the main titular character; he is a heroic and collected archeologist. Marion is a tough and sassy bar tender who became Indy's partner and eventually a tormented damsel-in-distress. John Rhys-Davis is great as Indy's close friend "Sallah" with his amusing performance. Paul Freeman plays Rene, an ambitious jerk who is Indy's arch-nemesis, while Ronald Lacey is creepy as Major Arnold the Gestapo agent.In conclusion: With slick sophistication that offers superbly-staged set-pieces in spades throughout it's breezy pace, "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is a dynamic and rip-roaring non-stop ride of an adventure yarn with rollicking fun, breathtaking audacity, and sheer brilliance. Suitable for teens thirteen and up.

title: 7.9/10 - Creative, Iconic and Consistently Urgent, Raiders is Quite a Fun Watching Experience
content: Elaborate a bit more on that.Raiders of the Lost Ark follows, as written above, Indiana Jones - the smart, badass and fearless (as long as snakes are not around) archeologist and adventurer, who often goes after buried archeological treasure in order to bring them to the museum he works with. Here the US government contacts him with a special task - finding the lost ark of the covenant, which is pursued by Hitler's soldiers as well (the film takes place in 1936). So, as you can probably imagine, finding the ark before the nazis is not an easy task.I guess that others could dive into George Lucas' deep character building or something (which I don't think is exactly the case), or Spielberg's stunning cinematography (which, again, I don't really find all that mind-blowing here), but I'm gonna be honest with you.Raiders of the Lost Ark is just a simple, creative and fun film to watch.The character building isn't bad, I just think that every character is quite simple and straight forward. Except for, maybe, Jones' relationship with religion, no character here has some psychological mystery that makes you think a little bit. And even that one isn't really developed here. Marion , btw, totally feels like she was written by a man. Not to say that men can't write amazing female characters, but rather to say that you can feel how she's written from a very specific point of view on women. Quite cliche, but not terrible. She's okay, I guess.The cinematography is, again, totally fine, and I have no problem with it whatsoever. It's decent.The real strength of the film is its creativity and the consistent sense of urgency. I don't think that there are many dull moments here, if any. Almost every scene something creative, exciting and awesome is happening. I think that it can spark the childish "oh no, he's not gonna make it!" in every viewer, even if deep inside we all know that he's gonna be fine, since he's the protagonist. The plot thrusts the viewer from one exciting, iconic moment to another, and it's quite a fun experience.The score is great too, btw. John Williams is a legendary composer, and the main theme to this movie is one of the most iconic themes of all time. For a good reason, I'd say.So, in conclusion: Raiders of the Lost Ark is not your deep, visually amazing masterpiece, but rather a very fun watching experience with many exciting, iconic moments. The characters are simple but they work well with the plot, and I guess that this is what matters most here. Again, a lot of fun. I'm feeling a 7.9/10 on this one.

title: One time watch
content: Interesting beginning because i always like adventurous movies.But in the later part it seems uninteresting. I dont know why but in all indiana jones movie, native people seems uninvolved and fools. Whats the problem with this western people.Well, it is a good watch.

title: Best of the Indiana Jones series and one of the all time greatest!
content: This is by far and away the best movie in a trilogy of great movies. After establishing the fact that Indiana is a likable and yet not immortal hero, that the suspense never stops and that the characters still have room to be developed, there are two other things that really make this movie incredible.First, Marion Ravenwood is the best heroine of the series. If there's a possible rip against the next two, it is her absence. She is tough and aware of the events, and yet she is still beautiful and perfectly ladylike. It might seem like somewhat of a contradiction, but to anyone whos seen it, they know what I'm talking about. Elsa Scheider and Willie Scott of the later movies simply don't match up to Marion.Second, the movie is incredibly clever in that Indiana, despite all the trouble he faces, has absolutely no impact on the outcome. He could have told the government to shove it, and it would not have mattered. The Nazis eventually open the Ark, only to find that to be a somewhat gruesome thing. Its a funny irony, that the artifact they are so desperately looking for is better left untouched. Some might see this as bad, but I thought it was an interesting twist, and it does NOT ruin the movie at all. Besides, all the action and humor leading up to that point should more than make up for anyone who disliked that aspect.Either way, this movie is, IMO, the greatest of all time, a real must see!PS, I've just seen some negative reviews, and just like it was with When Harry Met Sally, most of the whiners seem to be coming from foreign countries, like France and Germany (who of course have a long history of popping out excellent movies...lol). None of them seem to have any good reason to rip the movie except that they're disappointed to see their own people getting beat up on. Oh, jealousy...

title: great film!
content: Dr Jones, Indiana Jones played by Harrison Ford, is an archaeologist and part time professor who goes on a mission to get the Ark of the Covenant before Nazi forces retrieve because of the power it is believed to have. Indiana Jones has an arch-nemesis in this film, Rene Belloq, played by Paul Freeman. He is also an archaeologist and the main antagonist in the film. He is Indiana Jones enemy, who is very smart and helps the Nazis search for the Ark of the Covenant. Upon discovering that the Nazis are also on the hunt for the Ark in Egypt, Indiana Jones then reunites with a former love interest and they team up together to try and get to the Ark first. Marion Ravenwood played by Karen Allen, is the former romantic interest of Indiana Jones. This story continues with Indiana Jones going on adventures and facing his rivals and facing many difficulties along the way.The two main themes of Raiders of the Lost Ark are the fight between good vs. Evil and exploration. Indiana Jones is very selfless and portrays the "good" guy well throughout the film. He is willing to risk his life to get the ark before the Nazis, he is fearless and willing to find knowledge no matter it takes by going on life-risking adventures. Whereas the evil guys in the film are the Nazis and Belloq.
